title: Amazon’s big spring sale continues, and we found the 100 best deals

title: I’m still testing the new Razer Blade 16 and I have mixed feelings
snippets: The Razer Blade 16 is a gaming laptop that aims to be an alternative to the MacBook Pro, featuring a design that balances gaming capabilities with a thin and light chassis. This marks a return to a more streamlined design after the previous generation increased in size.

title: BougeRV’s telescopic lantern is ridiculously versatile
snippets: BougeRV's LED lantern, marketed as an outdoor camplight, functions as a versatile work lamp suitable for various settings needing additional light. It is rechargeable, portable, and features three adjustable LED panels that emit 3000 lumens, making it ideal for use at campsites, workspaces, or for mechanical work.
summary: BougeRV has released a portable LED lantern designed for outdoor camping and versatile enough for workspaces or mechanical tasks. This rechargeable light offers 3000 lumens through three adjustable LED panels, catering to different lighting needs.

title: Judge saves the CFPB, for now
snippets: On Friday, Judge Amy Berman Jackson issued a preliminary injunction preventing the Trump administration and the Department of Government Efficiency from dismantling the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau (CFPB) until a final decision is made in the ongoing court case.
summary: On Friday, Judge Amy Berman Jackson issued a preliminary injunction that stops the Trump administration and the Department of Government Efficiency from dismantling the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau (CFPB) until a final ruling is made in the current court case.

title: Windows 11 is closing a loophole that let you skip making a Microsoft account

summary: Microsoft's latest update to the Windows 11 Insider Preview will eliminate a script that permitted users to install the operating system without needing an internet connection or to log into an account.

title: The 30 best Amazon Big Spring Sale deals under $30

title: Elon Musk’s xAI buys Elon Musk’s X for $33 billion on paper
snippets: Elon Musk announced that his AI company, xAI, has acquired the social media platform X (previously Twitter) in an all-stock deal. The transaction values xAI at $80 billion and X at $33 billion, which includes $12 billion in debt. This acquisition comes a few years after Musk bought Twitter for $44 billion.
summary: Elon Musk's AI company, xAI, has acquired the social media platform X (formerly known as Twitter) in an all-stock transaction. The deal values xAI at $80 billion and X at $33 billion, incorporating $12 billion of debt. This follows Musk's earlier purchase of Twitter for $44 billion a few years ago.

title: Microsoft tests Quick Machine Recovery to restore PCs that can’t boot
snippets: Microsoft has begun testing Quick Machine Recovery in its latest Windows Insider Preview build (6120.3653), aimed at enabling IT professionals to remotely recover Windows 11 devices that won't boot. This feature, first announced last year, is designed to prevent incidents similar to the previous Crowdstrike catastrophe.
summary: Microsoft is testing a new feature called Quick Machine Recovery in the latest Windows Insider Preview build (6120.3653) for Windows 11. This tool allows IT professionals to remotely fix devices that won't boot, aiming to avoid problems like the past Crowdstrike issue.

title: The Fitbit-to-Google account migration deadline moves to 2026

summary: Google has postponed the deadline for Fitbit users to transfer their accounts to Google accounts until next year. This decision follows Google's acquisition of Fitbit in early 2021. title: Researchers identify mutations that can lead to resistance to some chemotherapies
snippets: Investigators have discovered that mutations in VPS35, a crucial part of a pathway that uses reactive oxygen species (ROS) to destroy cancer cells, can lead to resistance to chemotherapy. This finding may aid in identifying tumors that are resistant to treatments.
summary: Researchers have found that mutations in the VPS35 gene, which is involved in a process that eliminates cancer cells using reactive oxygen species (ROS), can cause tumors to become resistant to chemotherapy. This discovery could help in identifying which tumors will not respond to treatment.

title: Discrimination-related depression, anxiety pronounced among multiracial, White, Asian populations
snippets: A study revealed that over 50% of US adults have faced discrimination, with those highly exposed being over five times more likely to show signs of depression and anxiety. Compared to those unaffected, individuals experiencing discrimination have almost nine times higher odds of screening positive for both mental health conditions.
summary: A study found that over half of US adults have experienced discrimination, leading to a significant increase in mental health issues. Those facing high levels of discrimination are over five times more likely to exhibit depression and anxiety symptoms. Additionally, individuals who have encountered discrimination have nearly nine times the risk of screening positive for both conditions compared to those who have not faced discrimination.

title: Meniscus injuries may soon be treated by customizable hydrogel
snippets: A new customizable hydrogel, created using 3D printing, showed promising results in preclinical trials for repairing various types of meniscal tears.
summary: Researchers have developed a new 3D-printed hydrogel that can be customized to repair different types of meniscal tears. This hydrogel showed promising outcomes in preclinical trials, indicating potential for future use in meniscal repair.

title: Cold plunges actually change your cells
snippets: Cold water immersion for a week has been found to boost cells' ability to handle stress by improving cellular resilience and autophagic function. This adaptation may contribute to better health, disease prevention, and a slower aging process at the cellular level.
summary: A study found that immersing in cold water for a week enhances cells' stress response, cellular resilience, and autophagy. This adaptation could lead to improved health, disease prevention, and slower cellular aging.

title: Researchers develop new DNA test for personalized treatment of bacterial vaginosis
snippets: Approximately one-third of women aged 14-49 in the U.S. experience bacterial vaginosis (BV), marked by odors and possible painful side effects. Over half of those treated with the first-line antibiotic, metronidazole, see a recurrence. Researchers have now created a DNA PCR-based lab test to enable precise treatment by analyzing the bacteria responsible for BV, aiming to improve treatment efficacy.
summary: In the U.S., about one-third of women aged 14-49 suffer from bacterial vaginosis (BV), which can cause odors and discomfort. Over 50% of patients treated with the standard antibiotic, metronidazole, experience a recurrence. Researchers have developed a DNA PCR-based lab test to identify the specific bacteria causing BV, with the goal of enhancing treatment effectiveness.

title: Why scientists are worried about weasels
snippets: Researchers have discovered that red meat, enhanced with scent oils, is the most effective bait for capturing weasel images on camera traps. This finding aids conservationists in tracking weasel populations, as these animals are notoriously hard to photograph.
summary: Researchers have found that using red meat with added scent oils is the best bait for photographing weasels with camera traps. This method improves the ability of conservationists to monitor weasel populations, which are difficult to capture on camera.

title: Artificial neurons organize themselves
snippets: Researchers have developed novel artificial neurons that can learn independently, closely mimicking biological neurons. These infomorphic neurons form artificial neural networks, learning self-organizedly by extracting information from their surrounding network environment.
summary: Researchers have created artificial neurons that can learn on their own, similar to how human neurons function. These neurons, part of artificial neural networks, can self-organize and learn by analyzing information from their environment.

title: Brain channels 'stopped in time' reveal chemical flow that enables learning and thinking
snippets: A recent study has discovered findings that could help in the development of new medications. These drugs would target signaling channels in the body, aiming to either block or open them. This advancement has the potential to treat a range of conditions, including epilepsy and certain intellectual disorders.
summary: A recent study has identified potential advancements in medication development by targeting signaling channels in the body to treat conditions such as epilepsy and some intellectual disorders. The research focuses on creating drugs that can either block or open these channels, offering new treatment possibilities.
